questions.text: Two women of age 30 and 48 years come for screening for breast tumour. They were Tested with two different tests. Which of these represent correctly the test done respectively on these women?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRI and Mammography Routine Screening for breast cancer done for women above the age of 40 years. Preferred modality above the age of 40 years is mammography but below 40 years because of high density of breast tissue preferred modality is USG. USG Is IOC for any cystic pathology in breast tissue as well as to investigate any mass below the age of 40 years.

Highyeild:

Mammography is the process of using low-energy X-rays to examine the human breast for diagnosis and screening. The goal of mammography is the early detection of breast cancer, typically through detection of characteristic masses or microcalcifications .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. MRI done in high-risk patients or recurrent breast cancer since mammography and USG are poor in distinguishing postoperative scar from fresh cancer. Option: C. USG image of invasive breast cancer. Option: D. CT scan is not preferred modality for breast tissue since CT is better for bones and calcification but not soft tissue.

Extraedge:

In general, there are two main types of mammograms: Digital mammography in 2D. Digital mammography in 3D (digital breast tomosynthesis).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with mass in left breast which is non-mobile and non-tender on palpation. On examination, retraction of nipple was noticed with overlying skin changes. Following clinical examination mammography was done as a part of triple assessment. Which is most commonly the target for mammography?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Molybdenum Molybdenum target is used because it produces a low-energy spectrum with peaks of 17.5 and 19.6 kiloelectron volts (keV) , providing high contrast. A tungsten target is less desirable because it produces higher energies. The spectrum is refined further by adding a filter to reduce the proportion of radiation above and below the desired range. Molybdenum/molybdenum is the most frequently used combination of target/filter

Highyeild:

In conventional mammography, molybdenum (Mo) and rhodium (Rh) have usually been used as target and filter materials. However, with digital detectors and their energy responses, other choices have been introduced, such as tungsten (W), aluminum (Al), and silver (Ag).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Tungsten - rarely used as target material Option: C. Gold - not preferred for target material

Extraedge:

In digital mammography, a molybdenum/molybdenum spectrum delivers the lowest dose for a 2 cm breast, but gives the highest dose for thicker breasts. Tungsten/rhodium or rhodium/aluminium spectra provide the lowest doses at greater thicknesses.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman came for routine screening of breast cancer and underwent mammography. Identify the view of following image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MLO Mammography has mainly two views mediolateral oblique (MLO) and craniocaudal(CC) views. Other addition views include paddle view and true lateral view.

Highyeild:

The MLO view is taken with the x-ray beam directed from superomedial to inferolateral, usually at an angle of 30 to 60 degrees, with compression applied obliquely across the chest wall, perpendicular to the long axis of the pectoralis major muscle. The MLO projection is the only projection in which all the breast tissue can be demonstrated on a single image. For the CC view, the x-ray beam travels from superior to inferior. Positioning is achieved by pulling the breast up and forward away from the chest wall, with compression applied from above

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - A is for MLO view and B is for CC view. CC view image Paddle view and true lateral view are not routinely done.

Extraedge:

Screening mammography refers to an examination of an asymptomatic woman to detect clinically occult breast cancer. The screening examination includes two views of the breast, sometimes referred to as the “standard views” : a mediolateral oblique and a craniocaudal view

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman come with complaint of breast mass since 1 year. On examination the mass was present in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Which is the best next radiological investigation for her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MLO view mammography Preferred investigation above 40 years of age is mammography so USG and CT scan are not the next best radiological investigation. To visualise upper outer quadrant of breast that involve axillary tail best view is MLO. In CC view axillary tail is diﬃcult to visualise.

Highyeild:

In screening digital mammography , each breast is typically imaged with two different views, i.e., the mediolateral oblique (MLO) view and cranial caudal (CC) view . The MLO view is taken from the center of the chest outward, while the CC view is taken from above the breast

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. CC view mammography - axillary tail is diﬃcult to visualise. Option: C. USG Option: D. CT scan Mammography is better investigation here as compare to usg and CT scan.

Extraedge:

The mediolateral oblique (MLO) view is one of the two standard mammographic views, alongside the craniocaudal (CC) view. It is the most important projection as it allows depiction of most breast tissue.

questions.text: A young lactating woman present with complaint of high-grade fever, Well-defined fluctuant lump in the aﬀected breast. Pain in the aﬀected breast. Redness, swelling, and tenderness in an area of the breast. Her mammography was done and the following image was obtained. Identify the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breast cysts Above clinical scenario is suggestive of breast abscess. Breast cyst is more common in lactating females. On mammography they are seen as well-defined, round or oval masses. Sometimes a characteristic halo is visible on mammography. Ultrasound also demonstrates well-defined margins, with an oval or round shape.

Highyeild:

Breast cysts develop as a result of fluid accumulation inside the glands in the breasts. Breast cysts may be defined by their size: Microcysts may be seen during imaging tests, such as mammography or ultrasound, but are too small to feel.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Fibroadenoma - Fibroadenoma on mammography, fibroadenomas are seen as well-defined, rounded or oval masses . Coarse calcifications may develop within fibroadenomas called popcorn calcification. Option: B. Inflammatory breast cancer - Carcinomas typically appear as ill-defined or spiculated masses on mammography. Option: D. Fat necrosis - Fat necrosis appears as egg shell calcification on mammography.

Extraedge:

Cysts appearance on a mammogram Breast cyst on ultrasound On a mammogram, they can sometimes be seen as a smooth, round mass in the breast tissue. On ultrasound, they are usually smooth, round and black. Sometimes cysts do not have these typical features and they are difficult to distinguish from solid (non-fluid) lesions just by looking.

questions.text: A 20 year old lady presents with c/o mass in left breast which is firm, smooth, rubbery and has a well-defined shape, painless, moving easily under her skin when examined. Identify the correct mammography finding for the above mentioned scenario ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Popcorn calcification The given clinical scenario and age group is suggestive of fibroadenoma. Fibroadenoma present as popcorn calcification on mammography

Highyeild:

Egg shell calcification are characteristic of fat necrosis Broken needle and lead pipe calcification are characteristic of duct ectasia which is usually bilateral. EXTRA POINT : Fibroadenomas must be distinguished from well-circumscribed carcinomas; this is done by percutaneous biopsy. Phyllodes tumour can also have a similar appearance to fibroadenoma , leading to diagnostic difficulties

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Egg shell calcification - characteristic of fat necrosis Option: C. Broken needle calcification -characteristic of duct ectasia Option: D. Lead pipe calcification - Seen in traumatic fat necrosis

Extraedge:

Fat necrosis within the breast is a pathological process that occurs when there is saponification of local fat. It is a benign inflammatory process and is becoming increasingly common with the greater use of breast-conserving surgery and mammoplasty procedures.

questions.text: A 65 year old woman with a history of breast cancer in right breast operated 1 year back come for follow up checkup and her mammography was done as shown in image. What should be done in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Excision or wider sampling from the area of suspect

questions.correct_answer: A. Excision or wider sampling from the area of suspect
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Excision or wider sampling from the area of suspect Given image demonstrate A surveillance mammogram on a patient who has undergone a previous wide excision for a screen-detected cancer. The surgical scar (arrow) contains an area of lucency and coarse calcifications indicating associated fat necrosis. A small spiculate mass is demonstrated adjacent to the surgical scar (arrowhead); So,next step should be Excision or wider sampling from the area of suspect(Epithelial atypia, DCIS and invasive carcinoma may be found in association with radial scars and so excision or wider sampling is recommended.).

Highyeild:

Usg and mammography won’t diﬀerentiate between scar and breast cancer. MRI is preferred investigation to diﬀerentiate surgical scar from mass, thus excluding the other options.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Continue regular follow up - Excision is needed as cancer can be suspected . Option: C. Do USG- won’t diﬀerentiate between scar and breast cancer. Option: D. Do CT scan - usually not done

Extraedge:

Tissue around the lump is also removed. This surgery is called an excisional breast biopsy, or lumpectomy. When a noncancerous tumor such as a fibroadenoma of the breast is removed, this is also called an excisional breast biopsy, or a lumpectomy.

questions.text: A 30 year old lady present with complain of mass in left breast and history of trauma few days back. Mammography was done as shown in image? Identify the condition:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fat necrosis Fat necrosis is a frequently encountered cause of benign calcifications, particularly when there is a history of trauma or previous surgery . It may present as ‘egg shell’ calcifications within the wall of an oil cyst or as coarse dystrophic calcifications associated with areas of scarring.

Highyeild:

Fibroadenoma present with popcorn calcification as shown Duct ectasia appears as broken needle on mammography Fibrocystic disease give teacup appearance

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Duct ectasia - Broken needle calcification Option: C. Fibroadenoma - popcorn calcification Option: D. Fibrocystic disease- Tea cup appearance

Extraedge:

Fat necrosis within the breast is a pathological process that occurs when there is saponification of local fat. It is a benign inflammatory process and is becoming increasingly common with the greater use of breast-conserving surgery and mammoplasty procedures.

questions.text: A 45 year old woman come with complaint greenish nipple discharge from both nipples Tenderness in the nipple or surrounding breast tissue (areola). Redness of the nipple and areolar tissue. A breast lump or thickening near the clogged duct. Identify the correct mammography image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A Duct ectasia Image A shows broken needle appearance which is suggestive of duct ectasia

Highyeild:

Ductal ectasia is often asymptomatic, especially when benign . However, patients with ductal ectasia may present with nonspecific breast symptoms: nipple discharge nipple retraction pain/tenderness palpable mass

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Image B is suggestive of egg shell calcification of fat necrosis Image C is suggestive of teacup appearance of fibrocystic disease. Image D is suggestive of postoperative scar.

Extraedge:

Mammary duct ectasia occurs when one or more milk ducts beneath your nipple widens. The duct walls may thicken, and the duct may fill with fluid. The milk duct may become blocked or clogged with a thick, sticky substance

questions.text: A 65 year old lady present with mass in left breast since 1 year which is increasing in size. Mass was fixed, not mobile and associated with skin changes. Skin changes are defined as peau d orange appearance. Her mammography was done . Identify the mammography finding:
questions.correct_answer: C. Small cluster of indeterminate calcification
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Small cluster of indeterminate calcification Given Mammographic image shows small cluster of indeterminate calcification which is suggestive of breast cancer. Clustered calcification is more suggestive of cancer as compared to scattered calcification.

Highyeild:

Grouped (or clustered) calcifications , which are defined as at least five calcifications with- in 1 cm3 of tissue, are most often of interme- diate concern for malignancy of the breast. Linear calcifications, which suggest deposits in a duct, are suspicious for malignancy

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Egg shell calcification suggestive of fat necrosis Popcorn calcification more suggestive of fibroadenoma Rod shaped or branching calcification suggestive of duct ectasia or DCIS.

Extraedge:

Smaller breast calcifications, known as microcalcifications , may appear in patterns. If several calcifications look like a line or are clustered together as a small group, they are suggestive of cancer. These patients need additional testing. For calcifications that look suspicious, patients need additional tests.

questions.text: A 40 year old woman come for regular screening for breast cancer and her mammography was suggestive of localised lesion in right breast but on further investigation the result was false positive. A new technique was develop to reduce false positivity rate of mammography. Technique named digital breast tomosynthesis. Which is incorrect statement for DBT?

options.label: A
options.text: DBT is a mammography technique producing thin slice images reducing the effects of tissue superimposition

options.label: B
options.text: DBT can improve sensitivity and specificity of breast cancer screening by increasing cancer detection rates

options.label: C
options.text: DBT is replacing the traditional spot compression view

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above All above statements are correct One of the limitations of mammography is that it produces a 2D radiographic view of what is a 3D structure and, as a consequence, cancers may not be detected due to overlapping normal glandular tissue obscuring the presence of a tumour, leading to false negative interpretations. This is a particular issue in women with a denser background glandular pattern, typically younger, pre-menopausal women, where the sensitivity of mammography for detecting malignancy may be below 50%. In addition, lesions may be simulated by the superimposition of normal tissue, leading to false positive interpretations and unnecessary recalls following screening mammography. Breast tomosynthesis (DBT) is a digital mammographic technique which aims to alleviate these issues. It produces thin slices through the breast, reconstructed from multiple low-dose projections acquired at different angles of the x-ray tube.

Highyeild:

SUMMARY BOX: Digital Breast Tomosynthesis DBT is a mammographic technique producing thin slice images through the breast, reducing the effects of tissue superimposition DBT can improve the sensitivity and specificity of breast cancer screening by increasing cancer detection rates and reducing recall rates • DBT is replacing the traditional spot compression view in the work-up of screen detected abnormalities

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. D BT is a mammography technique producing thin slice images reducing the effects of tissue superimposition Option B . DBT can improve sensitivity and specificity of breast cancer screening by increasing cancer detection rates Option C . DBT is replacing the traditional spot compression view Options A,B,C all are correct.

Extraedge:

Tomosynthesis or “3D” mammography is a new type of digital x-ray mammogram which creates 2D and 3D-like pictures of the breasts. This tool improves the ability of mammography to detect early breast cancers, and decreases the number of women “called back” for additional tests for findings that are not cancers.

questions.text: A 65 year old lady come with mass in right breast and later on mammography BIRAD 5 was present. Biopsy was suggested. Which of the following is incorrect statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Mammographic or USG guided biopsy can be done

options.label: B
options.text: USG guided biopsy is preferred over mammographic guided

options.label: C
options.text: Mammographic guided biopsy can't be done

options.label: D
options.text: Mammmography can be used for preoperative localisation procedure

questions.correct_answer: C. Mammographic guided biopsy can't be done
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mammographic guided biopsy can't be done Mammographic guided biopsy can't be done, although USG is best to guide biopsy and more preferred over mammography.

Highyeild:

The main indications for mammography are in women over the age of 40 to evaluate breast symptoms and signs, including masses, skin thickening, deformity, nipple retraction, nipple discharge and nipple eczema. It is the primary technique for breast cancer screening and for follow-up of patients with previously treated breast cancer. It can also be used to guide biopsy and preoperative localisation procedures.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A,B,D are correct. Although USG is best to guide biopsy and more preferred over mammography.

Extraedge:

An ultr asound-guided breast biopsy uses sound waves to help locate a lump or abnormality and remove a tissue sample for examination under a microscope. It is less invasive than surgical biopsy , leaves little to no scarring and does not involve exposure to ionizing radiation.

questions.text: A 40 year old woman come for regular screening of mammography. Two standard view of mammography was done that is MLO and CC view. Which of the following statement is wrong about these views ?

options.label: A
options.text: The MLO view is taken with the X-ray beam directed from superomedial to inferno lateral, usually at an angle of 30 to 60 degrees.

options.label: B
options.text: In MLO view compression applied obliquely across the chest wall.

options.label: C
options.text: For CC view ,X-ray beam travels from superior to inferior

options.label: D
options.text: CC view can demonstrate axillary tail of breast

questions.correct_answer: D. CC view can demonstrate axillary tail of breast
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CC view can demonstrate axillary tail of breast CC view can’t show axillary tail . CC view is best for medial side. For the CC view, the x-ray beam travels from superior to inferior. Positioning is achieved by pulling the breast up and forward away from the chest wall, with compression applied from above. A well-positioned CC view should demonstrate the nipple in profile. It should demonstrate virtually all of the medial tissue and most of the lateral tissue except the axillary tail of the breast.

Highyeild:

The MLO view is taken with the x-ray beam directed from superomedial to inferolateral, usually at an angle of 30 to 60 degrees, with compression applied obliquely across the chest wall, perpendicular to the long axis of the pectoralis major muscle . The MLO projection is the only projection in which all the breast tissue can be demonstrated on a single image.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A,B,C are correct A well-positioned CC view should demonstrate the nipple in profile. It should demonstrate virtually all of the medial tissue and most of the lateral tissue except the axillary tail of the breast.

Extraedge:

While CC view depicts the entire breast , MLO view reflects more of the breast in the upper-outer quadrant, giving the best view of the lateral side of the breast, which statistically is the most common place for pathological changes.

questions.text: A 40 year old woman come for regular screening of mammography. Two standard view of mammography was done. Identify the correct pair of view respectively:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A- MLO B- CC A is MLO view and B is CC view The MLO view is taken with the x-ray beam directed from superomedial to inferolateral, usually at an angle of 30 to 60 degrees , with compression applied obliquely across the chest wall, perpendicular to the long axis of the pectoralis major muscle.

Highyeild:

For the CC view, the x-ray beam travels from superior to inferior. Positioning is achieved by pulling the breast up and forward away from the chest wall, with compression applied from above.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B,C,D are incorrect as A is MLO view and B is CC view

Extraedge:

Standard views are bilateral craniocaudal (CC) and mediolateral oblique (MLO) views, which comprise routine screening mammography . The views are usually used for all routine screening clients. That is, unless there is a contraindication, screening mammograms consist of these 4 views

Standard views are bilateral craniocaudal (CC) and mediolateral oblique (MLO) views, which comprise routine screening mammography. The views are usually used for all routine screening clients. That is, unless there is a contraindication, screening mammograms consist of these 4 views.

questions.text: A 45 year old woman come for regular screening for breast cancer and mammography was done. Finding as shown in image. Identify the condition:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DCIS Ductal Carcinoma In Situ. Mammography shows the segmental distribution of pleomorphic microcalcifications. Granular, rod- shaped and branching calcifications can be identified. The appearances are typical of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ

Highyeild:

Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is the presence of abnormal cells inside a milk duct in the breast. DCIS is considered the earliest form of breast cancer. DCIS is noninvasive , meaning it hasn't spread out of the milk duct and has a low risk of becoming invasive.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Fibrocystic changes show teacups representing the layer out of calcific material in the dependent portion of microcysts on a lateral magnification view Fat necrosis appearance on mammography is egg shell calcification Fibroadenoma- popcorn calcification

Extraedge:

DCIS doesn't generally cause symptoms. A few people with DCIS may notice a breast lump, itchy skin or nipple discharge (like blood). Still, more than 90% of DCIS is discovered by imaging procedures, like mammograms.
